questions.question: What is the time complexity of searching an element in a sorted array using binary search?
Which data structure is best suited for implementing a 'Last-In, First-Out' (LIFO) behavior?
What is the primary disadvantage of using an array for data storage when frequent insertions/deletions are required at arbitrary positions?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a Singly Linked List?
questions.option3: Direct access to any element by index
questions.option4: Requires more memory than arrays for storing elements

questions.question: What is the worst-case time complexity of inserting an element at the beginning of an unsorted singly linked list?
In a Circular Linked List, how do you determine if the list is empty (assuming a single pointer 'last' points to the last node)?
questions.option4: Both last and last->next are NULL

questions.question: Which operation in a Doubly Linked List has a time complexity of O(1) if you have a pointer to the node to be deleted?
questions.option3: Inserting a node at a specific position by index

questions.question: What is the amortized time complexity of pushing an element onto a stack implemented using a dynamic array that resizes by doubling?
If a queue is implemented using a circular array with `front` and `rear` pointers (and one empty slot rule), what indicates a full queue?
Which of the following scenarios is a Queue data structure commonly used for?
questions.option4: Maintaining a history of visited web pages

questions.question: What is the maximum number of nodes at level 'k' (root is level 0) in a perfect binary tree?
Which tree traversal algorithm visits the root node first, then the left subtree, and finally the right subtree?
What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a Binary Search Tree (BST) in the worst case (e.g., a skewed tree)?
What is the primary advantage of an AVL tree over a standard BST?
questions.option2: Guaranteed O(log n) search, insertion, and deletion time complexity

questions.question: In a Red-Black Tree, which property states that all simple paths from a node to descendant null leaves contain the same number of black nodes?
questions.option1: Every node is either red or black.
questions.option3: Every red node must have two black child nodes.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of nodes in a complete binary tree of height 'h' (root at height 0)?
Which data structure is typically used to implement a priority queue efficiently?
What is the time complexity of building a heap from an unsorted array of 'n' elements using the bottom-up approach?
Which of the following is a characteristic of a B-tree of order 'm'?
questions.option1: All leaf nodes must be at different levels.
questions.option2: Each node can have at most 'm' keys.
questions.option3: Each internal node (except root) has at least $ lceil m/2 ceil$ children.
questions.option4: It is primarily used for in-memory data storage.

questions.question: What is the primary use case for a Trie (Prefix Tree)?
questions.option3: Efficient string searching and prefix matching

questions.question: What is a collision in a hash table?
questions.option1: When two different keys map to the same index.
questions.option2: When the hash table runs out of memory.
questions.option3: When a key cannot be found.
questions.option4: When the hash function is too slow.

questions.question: Which collision resolution technique involves calculating a new hash value using a secondary hash function if a collision occurs?
What is the average-case time complexity of searching for an element in a hash table with a good hash function and reasonable load factor?
What is the load factor of a hash table?
questions.option1: The total number of elements stored.
questions.option2: The ratio of the number of elements to the table size.
questions.option4: The average length of a chain in separate chaining.

questions.question: When is rehashing typically performed in a hash table?
questions.option2: When the load factor exceeds a certain threshold.
questions.option3: Only when the hash table is completely full.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of edges in a simple undirected graph with 'V' vertices?
Which graph traversal algorithm typically uses a queue to visit nodes?
What is the time complexity of Depth-First Search (DFS) on a graph represented using an adjacency list?
Dijkstra's algorithm is used to find:
questions.option2: Single-source shortest path in graphs with non-negative edge weights

questions.question: Which algorithm is commonly used to detect cycles in an undirected graph?
questions.option3: DFS with a visited array and checking for back edges

questions.question: What is a strongly connected component in a directed graph?
questions.option1: A subgraph where every pair of vertices is connected by an edge.
questions.option2: A component where all vertices have the same degree.
questions.option3: A maximal subgraph where for every pair of vertices (u, v), there is a path from u to v and a path from v to u.
questions.option4: A component that is connected to all other components.

questions.question: Which algorithm finds the Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) by iteratively adding the cheapest edge that connects two distinct components?
What data structure is typically used to implement Kruskal's algorithm efficiently?
questions.option3: Min-Heap (for edges) and Disjoint Set Union (for cycle detection)

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the Floyd-Warshall algorithm for all-pairs shortest path?
When would you prefer an adjacency matrix over an adjacency list for graph representation?
questions.option1: When the graph is sparse (few edges).
questions.option2: When you need to quickly check for the existence of an edge between two specific vertices.
questions.option3: When the graph has a very large number of vertices.
questions.option4: When performing BFS or DFS frequently.

questions.question: What is a splay tree?
questions.option1: A self-balancing binary search tree that brings recently accessed nodes closer to the root.
questions.option2: A tree where all leaves are at the same level.
questions.option3: A tree optimized for range queries.
questions.option4: A tree used to store spatial data.

questions.question: What is the amortized time complexity of an operation (like search, insert, delete) in a splay tree?
Which data structure is typically used for efficient prefix sum queries and point updates on an array?
What is the key advantage of a Skip List over balanced binary search trees?
questions.option1: Guaranteed O(log n) worst-case performance for all operations.
questions.option2: Simpler implementation with comparable average-case performance and good parallelism opportunities.

questions.question: What is a segment tree used for?
questions.option1: To represent a network flow problem.
questions.option2: To efficiently answer range queries (e.g., sum, min, max) and range updates on an array.
questions.option3: To store key-value pairs with fast lookups.
questions.option4: To find cycles in a graph.

questions.question: In a max-heap, where is the largest element always located?
questions.option3: At the last node of the last level.
questions.option4: At the node with the most children.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Disjoint Set Union (DSU) data structure?
questions.option1: To find the shortest path in a graph.
questions.option2: To maintain a collection of disjoint sets and efficiently perform union and find operations.
questions.option3: To store elements in sorted order.

questions.question: Which path compression technique in DSU makes every node on the path from an element to the root point directly to the root?
What is the time complexity of the 'find' and 'union' operations in a DSU with both path compression and union by rank/size (amortized)?
What is the primary application of topological sorting?
questions.option2: Determining a linear ordering of vertices in a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) such that for every directed edge (u, v), u comes before v in the ordering.
questions.option4: Detecting negative cycles in a graph.

questions.question: Which algorithm is suitable for finding the shortest path in a graph with negative edge weights, provided there are no negative cycles reachable from the source?
What is the main drawback of using an adjacency matrix for a very sparse graph?
questions.option2: High memory consumption ($O(V^2)$) and slow iteration over edges ($O(V^2)$).

questions.question: Which data structure would be most efficient for a spell checker that suggests words based on prefixes and stores a large dictionary?
Explain the concept of 'lazy propagation' in a segment tree.
questions.option1: It refers to delaying updates to child nodes until their range is queried or needs to be propagated further, to optimize performance for range updates.
questions.option2: It's a technique to make the tree self-balancing.
questions.option3: It's a method for compressing the tree's memory footprint.
questions.option4: It describes how elements are inserted into the tree in a non-strict order.

questions.question: What is the difference between a complete binary tree and a full binary tree?
questions.option1: A complete binary tree has all leaves at the same level, while a full binary tree fills levels from left to right.
questions.option2: A complete binary tree fills all levels except possibly the last, and the last level is filled from left to right. A full binary tree has every node with either zero or two children.
questions.option3: A complete binary tree is always balanced, while a full binary tree is not.
questions.option4: There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable.

questions.question: In a hash table using open addressing, what is primary clustering?
questions.option1: When multiple keys hash to the same initial index.
questions.option2: When a collision resolution technique like linear probing creates long sequences of occupied slots.
questions.option3: When keys are distributed unevenly across the hash table.
questions.option4: When the hash function produces identical hash values for different keys.

questions.question: Which data structure provides $O(1)$ average-case time complexity for insertion, deletion, and lookup, but $O(N)$ worst-case?
What is the 'height' of a binary tree?
questions.option1: The number of nodes along the longest path from the root to any leaf node.
questions.option2: The number of edges along the longest path from the root to any leaf node.
questions.option3: The total number of levels in the tree.
questions.option4: The number of leaves in the tree.

questions.question: When would a min-priority queue be preferred over a max-priority queue?
questions.option1: When you need to extract the smallest element efficiently.
questions.option2: When you need to extract the largest element efficiently.
questions.option3: When the order of insertion matters.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of deleting an arbitrary element from a hash table using linear probing in the worst case?
Which sorting algorithm's best-case time complexity is O(N log N) but worst-case is O(N^2) due to pivot selection?
What is the space complexity of BFS on a graph (in terms of V and E)?
Which data structure is suitable for efficiently finding the K-th smallest element in a dynamic set of elements?
questions.option3: Min-Heap (for k largest) or Max-Heap (for k smallest) or Order Statistic Tree

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of a B+ tree that makes it highly suitable for disk-based databases?
questions.option1: All data pointers are stored in internal nodes.
questions.option2: All leaf nodes are linked together forming a sequential access path.
questions.option3: It always has a height of log N.
questions.option4: It supports only exact match queries.

questions.question: When building an optimal Huffman tree, which data structure is most commonly used to repeatedly extract the two nodes with the smallest frequencies?
What is the maximum number of children an internal node can have in a B-tree of order 'm'?
Which of the following is an application of a Fenwick Tree (Binary Indexed Tree)?
questions.option1: Finding the shortest path in a graph.
questions.option2: Efficiently computing prefix sums and updating elements in an array.
questions.option3: Implementing a dictionary for spell checking.

questions.question: What is the core idea behind a Skip List?
questions.option1: To use multiple linked lists at different levels, allowing for faster traversal by skipping nodes.
questions.option2: To balance the tree by rotations during insertions and deletions.
questions.option3: To store data in a compressed format.
questions.option4: To use hashing for fast lookups.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of performing a range sum query on a Segment Tree with 'N' elements?
Which type of graph would typically use an adjacency list for more efficient memory usage?
questions.option4: Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) with many edges

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'rank' in the Union by Rank heuristic for DSU?
questions.option1: To track the number of elements in a set.
questions.option2: To keep track of the height of the tree representing the set, aiming to attach smaller trees to larger ones.
questions.option3: To assign a unique identifier to each set.
questions.option4: To count the number of times a set has been merged.

questions.question: In the context of graphs, what does a 'bridge' refer to?
questions.option1: An edge whose removal increases the number of connected components.
questions.option2: An edge that connects two nodes with the highest degree.
questions.option3: An edge that forms a cycle.
questions.option4: An edge with the highest weight.

questions.question: What is an articulation point (or cut vertex) in an undirected graph?
questions.option1: A vertex whose removal increases the number of connected components.
questions.option2: A vertex that has the highest degree.
questions.option3: A vertex that is part of every cycle.
questions.option4: A vertex that connects two bipartite components.

questions.question: Which algorithm is used to find the maximum flow in a flow network?
What is a directed acyclic graph (DAG)?
questions.option1: A directed graph that contains at least one cycle.
questions.option2: An undirected graph with no cycles.
questions.option3: A directed graph that contains no cycles.
questions.option4: A graph where all vertices have an outgoing edge.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of a self-balancing BST (like AVL or Red-Black) over a standard BST?
questions.option3: Guaranteed logarithmic time complexity for most operations.

questions.question: Which traversal of a BST produces elements in sorted order?
What is the optimal average-case time complexity for searching in a well-implemented hash table?
Which of the following is NOT a property of a min-heap?
questions.option1: The value of each node is less than or equal to the value of its children.
questions.option2: The smallest element is at the root.
questions.option3: It is a complete binary tree.
questions.option4: The order of elements at the same level is sorted.

questions.question: What is the time complexity to find the minimum element in a min-heap?
Which data structure is typically used for implementing browser history (back/forward functionality)?
questions.option1: Single Stack (for back), Second Stack (for forward)

questions.question: What is a 'doubly-ended queue' (deque)?
questions.option1: A queue that allows insertions only at the front and deletions only at the rear.
questions.option2: A queue that allows insertions and deletions from both ends.
questions.option3: A queue that has two front pointers.
questions.option4: A queue that can store two types of data.

questions.question: In memory management, which data structure is often used to implement a free list (available memory blocks)?
What is the main characteristic that differentiates a graph from a tree?
questions.option1: Graphs have cycles, trees do not.
questions.option2: Graphs can be disconnected, trees are always connected.
questions.option3: Graphs can have multiple parents, trees have only one parent per node (except root).

questions.question: What is the definition of a 'sparse graph'?
questions.option1: A graph where the number of edges is much less than the maximum possible number of edges ($O(V^2)$).
questions.option2: A graph with very few vertices.
questions.option4: A graph where all vertices have a low degree.

questions.question: Which algorithm is used to find the shortest path in a graph where edge weights can be negative, and negative cycles must be detected?
What is a strongly connected component in an undirected graph?
questions.option1: The concept of strongly connected components applies only to directed graphs.
questions.option2: A subgraph where every pair of vertices is connected by an edge.
questions.option3: A component where all vertices have the same degree.
questions.option4: A component that is connected to all other components.

questions.question: In a Red-Black Tree, what color is a newly inserted node always initially?
What is a persistent data structure?
questions.option1: A data structure that stores data on disk permanently.
questions.option2: A data structure that retains its previous versions when modified, allowing access to any version.
questions.option3: A data structure that automatically backs up its state.
questions.option4: A data structure whose operations are atomic.

questions.question: Which of the following sorting algorithms is stable (maintains the relative order of equal elements)?
What is the time complexity of merging two sorted linked lists of sizes M and N?
What is the primary benefit of using an indexed skip list over a regular skip list?
Which data structure is most suitable for implementing a Least Recently Used (LRU) cache?
questions.option3: Hash Map combined with a Doubly Linked List

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'sentinel node' in a linked list?
questions.option1: To store the total count of nodes.
questions.option2: To simplify edge cases (like empty list or insertion at head/tail) by always having dummy nodes at ends.
questions.option3: To mark the end of the list.

questions.question: How is a min-heap typically represented in an array?
questions.option1: Elements are stored in sorted order.
questions.option2: The parent node is always at index (i-1)/2, left child at 2i+1, right child at 2i+2.
questions.option3: It's stored as a linked list within the array.

questions.question: What is the primary application of a K-D Tree?
questions.option3: Organizing points in a K-dimensional space for efficient range searches and nearest neighbor queries.

questions.question: In network flow, what does 'residual capacity' refer to?
questions.option1: The maximum amount of flow that can still be sent through an edge.
questions.option2: The current flow passing through an edge.
questions.option3: The original capacity of an edge.
questions.option4: The total capacity of the network.

questions.question: What is the worst-case space complexity of recursion due to the call stack?
Which algorithm is used to find all-pairs shortest paths in a graph that can have negative edge weights (but no negative cycles)?
What is the 'in-degree' of a vertex in a directed graph?
questions.option1: The number of edges originating from the vertex.
questions.option2: The number of edges terminating at the vertex.
questions.option3: The total number of edges connected to the vertex.
questions.option4: The number of vertices reachable from it.

questions.question: What is the purpose of hashing in data structures?
questions.option2: To map data of arbitrary size to data of fixed size (hash value) for efficient storage and retrieval.
questions.option3: To compress data for memory saving.
questions.option4: To create a unique identifier for every element.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about a hash function?
questions.option2: It should distribute keys uniformly across the hash table.
questions.option3: It must produce unique hash values for all keys.
questions.option4: Its computation time should be O(n).

questions.question: What is a 'memory leak' in the context of data structures?
questions.option1: When a program attempts to access memory it doesn't own.
questions.option2: When dynamically allocated memory is no longer needed but is not deallocated, making it unavailable for future use.
questions.option4: When a pointer points to an invalid memory address.

questions.question: Which data structure is optimized for storing hierarchical data with parent-child relationships?
What is the primary difference between an Abstract Data Type (ADT) and a data structure?
questions.option1: An ADT is a concrete implementation, while a data structure is a logical model.
questions.option2: An ADT defines a set of operations and their behavior, independent of implementation, while a data structure is a concrete way to organize data to implement an ADT.
questions.option3: An ADT is only for theoretical concepts, while data structures are for practical programming.
questions.option4: There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable.
